an8.3:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an8.3:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.

an8.3:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appiyapasaṃsī ca hoti, piyagarahī ca, lābhakāmo ca, sakkārakāmo ca, ahiriko ca, anottappī ca, pāpiccho ca, micchādiṭṭhi ca.
an8.3:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant praises the disliked and criticizes the liked. They desire material things and honor. They lack conscience and prudence. They have corrupt wishes and wrong view.

an8.3:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an8.3:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.

an8.3:2.1.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an8.3:2.1.eng: A mendicant with eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.

an8.3:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na appiyapasaṃsī ca hoti, na piyagarahī ca, na lābhakāmo ca, na sakkārakāmo ca, hirīmā ca hoti, ottappī ca, appiccho ca, sammādiṭṭhi ca.
an8.3:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t praise the disliked and criticize the liked. They don’t desire material things and honor. They have conscience and prudence. They have few desires and right view.

an8.3:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an8.3:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.”

an8.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati suṃsumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
an8.30:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an8.30:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā anuruddho cetīsu viharati pācīnavaṃsadāye.
an8.30:1.2.eng: And at that time Venerable Anuruddha was staying in the land of the Cetīs in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.

an8.30:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmato anuruddhassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
an8.30:1.3.eng: Then as Anuruddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

an8.30:1.4.eng: “This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.

an8.30:1.5.eng: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.

an8.30:1.6.eng: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.

an8.30:1.7.eng: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.

an8.30:1.8.eng: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.

an8.30:1.9.eng: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.

an8.30:1.10.pli: paññavato ayaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassā”ti.
an8.30:1.10.eng: It’s for the wise, not the witless.”

an8.30:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato anuruddhassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—bhaggesu susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye antarahito cetīsu pācīnavaṃsadāye āyasmato anuruddhassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
an8.30:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha knew what Anuruddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood in the land of the Bhaggas and reappeared in front of Anuruddha in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall in the land of the Cetīs,

an8.30:2.2.eng: and sat on the seat spread out.

an8.30:2.3.pli: Āyasmāpi kho anuruddho bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an8.30:2.3.eng: Anuruddha bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

an8.30:2.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

an8.30:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, yaṃ taṃ mahāpurisavitakkaṃ vitakkesi:
an8.30:3.2.eng: It’s good that you reflect on these thoughts of a great man:

an8.30:3.3.eng: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.

an8.30:3.4.eng: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.

an8.30:3.5.eng: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.

an8.30:3.6.eng: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.

an8.30:3.7.eng: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.

an8.30:3.8.eng: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.

an8.30:3.9.pli: paññavato ayaṃ dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassā’ti.
an8.30:3.9.eng: It’s for the wise, not the witless.’

an8.30:3.10.pli: Tena hi tvaṃ, anuruddha, imampi aṭṭhamaṃ mahāpurisavitakkaṃ vitakkehi:
an8.30:3.10.eng: Well then, Anuruddha, you should also reflect on the following eighth thought of a great man:

an8.30:3.11.pli: ‘nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ dhammo nippapañcaratino, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassa papañcaratino’ti.
an8.30:3.11.eng: ‘This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.’

an8.30:4.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, tato tvaṃ, anuruddha, yāvadeva ākaṅkhissasi, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharissasi.
an8.30:4.1.eng: First you’ll reflect on these eight thoughts of a great man. Then as far as you want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, you’ll enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an8.30:5.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, tato tvaṃ, anuruddha, yāvadeva ākaṅkhissasi, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharissasi.
an8.30:5.1.eng: You’ll enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an8.30:6.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, tato tvaṃ, anuruddha, yāvadeva ākaṅkhissasi, pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharissasi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedissasi yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharissasi.
an8.30:6.1.eng: You’ll enter and remain in the third absorption, where you’ll meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

an8.30:7.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, tato tvaṃ, anuruddha, yāvadeva ākaṅkhissasi, sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharissasi.
an8.30:7.1.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, you’ll enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an8.30:8.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime ca aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, imesañca catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī bhavissasi akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, tato tuyhaṃ, anuruddha, seyyathāpi nāma gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nānārattānaṃ dussānaṃ dussakaraṇḍako pūro;
an8.30:8.1.eng: First you’ll reflect on these eight thoughts of a great man, and you’ll get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when you want, without trouble or difficulty. Then as you live contented your rag robe will seem to you like a chest full of garments of different colors seems to a householder or householder’s child.

an8.30:8.2.pli: evamevaṃ te paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ khāyissati santuṭṭhassa viharato ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
an8.30:8.2.eng: It will be for your enjoyment, relief, and comfort, and for alighting upon extinguishment.

an8.30:9.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime ca aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, imesañca catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī bhavissasi akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, tato tuyhaṃ, anuruddha, seyyathāpi nāma gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā sālīnaṃ odano vicitakāḷako anekasūpo anekabyañjano;
an8.30:9.1.eng: As you live contented your scraps of almsfood will seem to you like boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces seems to a householder or householder’s child.

an8.30:9.2.pli: evamevaṃ te piṇḍiyālopabhojanaṃ khāyissati santuṭṭhassa viharato ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
an8.30:9.2.eng: It will be for your enjoyment, relief, and comfort, and for alighting upon extinguishment.

an8.30:10.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime ca aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, imesañca catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī bhavissasi akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, tato tuyhaṃ, anuruddha, seyyathāpi nāma gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā kūṭāgāraṃ ullittāvalittaṃ nivātaṃ phusitaggaḷaṃ pihitavātapānaṃ;
an8.30:10.1.eng: As you live contented your lodging at the root of a tree will seem to you like a bungalow, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with door fastened and window shuttered seems to a householder or householder’s child.

an8.30:10.2.pli: evamevaṃ te rukkhamūlasenāsanaṃ khāyissati santuṭṭhassa viharato ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
an8.30:10.2.eng: It will be for your enjoyment, relief, and comfort, and for alighting upon extinguishment.

an8.30:11.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime ca aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, imesañca catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī bhavissasi akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, tato tuyhaṃ, anuruddha, seyyathāpi nāma gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā pallaṅko gonakatthato paṭikatthato paṭalikatthato kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇo sauttaracchado ubhatolohitakūpadhāno;
an8.30:11.1.eng: As you live contented your lodging at the root of a tree will seem to you like a couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends seems to a householder or householder’s child.

an8.30:11.2.pli: evamevaṃ te tiṇasanthārakasayanāsanaṃ khāyissati santuṭṭhassa viharato ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
an8.30:11.2.eng: It will be for your enjoyment, relief, and comfort, and for alighting upon extinguishment.

an8.30:12.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, anuruddha, ime ca aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, imesañca catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī bhavissasi akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, tato tuyhaṃ, anuruddha, seyyathāpi nāma gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nānābhesajjāni, seyyathidaṃ—sappi navanītaṃ telaṃ madhu phāṇitaṃ;
an8.30:12.1.eng: As you live contented your rancid urine as medicine will seem to you like various medicines—ghee, butter, oil, honey, and molasses—seem to a householder or householder’s child.

an8.30:12.2.pli: evamevaṃ te pūtimuttabhesajjaṃ khāyissati santuṭṭhassa viharato ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
an8.30:12.2.eng: It will be for your enjoyment, relief, and comfort, and for alighting upon extinguishment.

an8.30:12.3.pli: Tena hi tvaṃ, anuruddha, āyatikampi vassāvāsaṃ idheva cetīsu pācīnavaṃsadāye vihareyyāsī”ti.
an8.30:12.3.eng: Well then, Anuruddha, for the next rainy season residence you should stay right here in the land of the Cetīs in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.”

an8.30:12.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato paccassosi.

an8.30:13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—cetīsu pācīnavaṃsadāye antarahito bhaggesu susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye pāturahosīti.
an8.30:13.1.eng: After advising Anuruddha like this, the Buddha—as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Park of the East-Raftered Hall in the land of the Cetīs and reappeared in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow.

an8.30:13.2.eng: He sat on the seat spread out

an8.30:13.4.pli: “aṭṭha kho, bhikkhave, mahāpurisavitakke desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha …pe…
an8.30:13.4.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the eight thoughts of a great man. Listen …

an8.30:13.5.eng: And what are the eight thoughts of a great man?

an8.30:13.6.pli: Appicchassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo mahicchassa;
an8.30:13.6.eng: This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.

an8.30:13.7.pli: santuṭṭhassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo asantuṭṭhassa;
an8.30:13.7.eng: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.

an8.30:13.8.pli: pavivittassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo saṅgaṇikārāmassa;
an8.30:13.8.eng: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.

an8.30:13.9.pli: āraddhavīriyassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo kusītassa;
an8.30:13.9.eng: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.

an8.30:13.10.pli: upaṭṭhitassatissāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo muṭṭhassatissa;
an8.30:13.10.eng: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.

an8.30:13.11.pli: samāhitassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo asamāhitassa;
an8.30:13.11.eng: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.

an8.30:13.12.pli: paññavato ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassa;
an8.30:13.12.eng: It’s for the wise, not the witless.

an8.30:13.13.pli: nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo nippapañcaratino, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassa papañcaratino.
an8.30:13.13.eng: It’s for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.

an8.30:14.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.’

an8.30:14.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:14.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:14.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appiccho samāno ‘appicchoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, santuṭṭho samāno ‘santuṭṭhoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, pavivitto samāno ‘pavivittoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, āraddhavīriyo samāno ‘āraddhavīriyoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, upaṭṭhitassati samāno ‘upaṭṭhitassatīti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, samāhito samāno ‘samāhitoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, paññavā samāno ‘paññavāti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati, nippapañcārāmo samāno ‘nippapañcārāmoti maṃ jāneyyun’ti na icchati.
an8.30:14.3.eng: A mendicant with few wishes doesn’t wish: ‘May they know me as having few wishes!’ When contented, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as contented!’ When secluded, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as secluded!’ When energetic, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as energetic!’ When mindful, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as mindful!’ When immersed, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as immersed!’ When wise, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as wise!’ When not enjoying proliferation, they don’t wish: ‘May they know me as one who doesn’t enjoy proliferating!’

an8.30:14.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.’

an8.30:14.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:14.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:15.1.pli: ‘Santuṭṭhassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo asantuṭṭhassā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:15.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for the contented, not those who lack contentment.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:15.2.eng: It’s for a mendicant who’s content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an8.30:15.3.eng: ‘This teaching is for the contented, not those who lack contentment.’

an8.30:15.4.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:15.4.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:16.1.pli: ‘Pavivittassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo saṅgaṇikārāmassā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:16.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:16.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato bhavanti upasaṅkamitāro bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo rājāno rājamahāmattā titthiyā titthiyasāvakā.
an8.30:16.2.eng: It’s for a mendicant who lives secluded. But monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their chief ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples go to visit them.

an8.30:16.3.pli: Tatra bhikkhu vivekaninnena cittena vivekapoṇena vivekapabbhārena vivekaṭṭhena nekkhammābhiratena aññadatthu uyyojanikapaṭisaṃyuttaṃyeva kathaṃ kattā hoti.
an8.30:16.3.eng: With a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, that mendicant invariably gives a talk concerned only with sending them away.

an8.30:16.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.’

an8.30:16.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:16.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:17.1.pli: ‘Āraddhavīriyassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo kusītassā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:17.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for the energetic, not the lazy.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an8.30:17.2.eng: It’s for a mendicant who lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an8.30:17.3.eng: ‘This teaching is for the energetic, not the lazy.’

an8.30:17.4.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:17.4.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:18.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for the mindful, not the unmindful.’

an8.30:18.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:18.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:18.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
an8.30:18.3.eng: It’s for a mendicant who’s mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

an8.30:18.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for the mindful, not the unmindful.’

an8.30:18.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:18.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:19.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for those with immersion, not those without immersion.’

an8.30:19.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:19.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:19.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.30:19.3.eng: It’s for a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an8.30:19.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for those with immersion, not those without immersion.’

an8.30:19.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:19.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:20.1.pli: ‘Paññavato ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassā’ti,
an8.30:20.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for the wise, not the witless.’

an8.30:20.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:20.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:20.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an8.30:20.3.eng: It’s for a mendicant who’s wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an8.30:20.4.pli: ‘Paññavato ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nāyaṃ dhammo duppaññassā’ti,
an8.30:20.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for the wise, not the witless.’

an8.30:20.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an8.30:20.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an8.30:21.1.pli: ‘Nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo nippapañcaratino, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassa papañcaratino’ti,
an8.30:21.1.eng: ‘This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.’

an8.30:21.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
an8.30:21.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

an8.30:21.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno papañcanirodhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
an8.30:21.3.eng: It’s for a mendicant whose mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided regarding the cessation of proliferation.

an8.30:21.4.pli: ‘Nippapañcārāmassāyaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammo, nippapañcaratino, nāyaṃ dhammo papañcārāmassa papañcaratino’ti,
an8.30:21.4.eng: ‘This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating and don’t like to proliferate, not for those who enjoy proliferating and like to proliferate.’

an8.30:21.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an8.30:21.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an8.30:22.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho āyatikampi vassāvāsaṃ tattheva cetīsu pācīnavaṃsadāye vihāsi.
an8.30:22.1.eng: Then Anuruddha stayed the next rainy season residence right there in the land of the Cetīs in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.

an8.30:22.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
an8.30:22.2.eng: And Anuruddha, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an8.30:22.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
an8.30:22.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

an8.30:22.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā anuruddho arahataṃ ahosīti.
an8.30:22.4.eng: And Venerable Anuruddha became one of the perfected.

an8.30:22.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho arahattappatto tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
an8.30:22.5.eng: And on the occasion of attaining perfection he recited these verses:

an8.30:23.2.eng: the supreme Teacher in the world

an8.30:23.3.eng: came to me in a mind-made body,

an8.30:25.4.eng: and have fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.”

an8.31:1.3.eng: Someone might give a gift after insulting the recipient.

an8.31:1.4.eng: Or they give out of fear.

an8.31:1.5.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘They gave to me.’

an8.31:1.6.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘They’ll give to me.’

an8.31:1.7.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘It’s good to give.’

an8.31:1.8.pli: ‘ahaṃ pacāmi, ime na pacanti; nārahāmi pacanto apacantānaṃ dānaṃ adātun’ti dānaṃ deti,
an8.31:1.8.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’

an8.31:1.9.pli: ‘imaṃ me dānaṃ dadato kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchatī’ti dānaṃ deti,
an8.31:1.9.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘By giving this gift I’ll get a good reputation.’

an8.31:1.10.eng: Or they give thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’

an8.32:1.3.eng: For this, they say, is the path of the gods,

an8.32:1.4.eng: which leads to the heavenly realm.”

an8.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight grounds for giving.

an8.33:1.3.pli: Chandā dānaṃ deti, dosā dānaṃ deti, mohā dānaṃ deti, bhayā dānaṃ deti, ‘dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ pitupitāmahehi, nārahāmi porāṇaṃ kulavaṃsaṃ hāpetun’ti dānaṃ deti, ‘imāhaṃ dānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissāmī’ti dānaṃ deti, ‘imaṃ me dānaṃ dadato cittaṃ pasīdati, attamanatā somanassaṃ upajāyatī’ti dānaṃ deti, cittālaṅkāracittaparikkhāratthaṃ dānaṃ deti.
an8.33:1.3.eng: Someone might give a gift out of favoritism or hostility or stupidity or cowardice. Or they give thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’ Or they give thinking, ‘After I’ve given this gift, when my body breaks up, after death, I’ll be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ Or they give thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’ Or they give a gift thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’

an8.33:1.4.eng: These are the eight grounds for giving.”

an8.34:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgate, bhikkhave, khette bījaṃ vuttaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahassādaṃ na phātiseyyaṃ.
an8.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a field has eight factors a seed sown in it is not very fruitful or rewarding or productive.

an8.34:1.2.eng: What eight factors does it have?

an8.34:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, khettaṃ unnāmaninnāmi ca hoti, pāsāṇasakkharikañca hoti, ūsarañca hoti, na ca gambhīrasitaṃ hoti, na āyasampannaṃ hoti, na apāyasampannaṃ hoti, na mātikāsampannaṃ hoti, na mariyādasampannaṃ hoti.
an8.34:1.3.eng: It’s when a field has mounds and ditches. It has stones and gravel. It’s salty. It doesn’t have deep furrows. And it’s not equipped with water inlets, water outlets, irrigation channels, and boundaries.

an8.34:1.4.pli: Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgate, bhikkhave, khette bījaṃ vuttaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahassādaṃ na phātiseyyaṃ.
an8.34:1.4.eng: When a field has these eight factors a seed sown in it is not fruitful or rewarding or productive.

an8.34:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ na mahājutikaṃ na mahāvipphāraṃ.
an8.34:2.1.eng: In the same way, when an ascetic or brahmin has eight factors a gift given to them is not very fruitful or beneficial or brilliant or bountiful.

an8.34:2.2.eng: What eight factors do they have?

an8.34:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā micchādiṭṭhikā honti, micchāsaṅkappā, micchāvācā, micchākammantā, micchāājīvā, micchāvāyāmā, micchāsatino, micchāsamādhino.
an8.34:2.3.eng: It’s when an ascetic or brahmin has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

an8.34:2.4.pli: Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatesu, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu dānaṃ dinnaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti na mahānisaṃsaṃ na mahājutikaṃ na mahāvipphāraṃ.
an8.34:2.4.eng: When an ascetic or brahmin has these eight factors a gift given to them is not very fruitful or beneficial or brilliant or bountiful.

an8.34:3.1.pli: Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgate, bhikkhave, khette bījaṃ vuttaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahassādaṃ phātiseyyaṃ.
an8.34:3.1.eng: When a field has eight factors a seed sown in it is very fruitful and rewarding and productive.

an8.34:3.2.eng: What eight factors does it have?

an8.34:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, khettaṃ anunnāmāninnāmi ca hoti, apāsāṇasakkharikañca hoti, anūsarañca hoti, gambhīrasitaṃ hoti, āyasampannaṃ hoti, apāyasampannaṃ hoti, mātikāsampannaṃ hoti, mariyādasampannaṃ hoti.
an8.34:3.3.eng: It’s when a field doesn’t have mounds and ditches. It doesn’t have stones and gravel. It’s not salty. It has deep furrows. And it’s equipped with water inlets, water outlets, irrigation channels, and boundaries.

an8.34:3.4.pli: Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgate, bhikkhave, khette bījaṃ vuttaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahassādaṃ phātiseyyaṃ.
an8.34:3.4.eng: When a field has these eight factors a seed sown in it is very fruitful and rewarding and productive.

an8.34:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsaṃ mahājutikaṃ mahāvipphāraṃ.
an8.34:4.1.eng: In the same way, when an ascetic or brahmin has eight factors a gift given to them is very fruitful and beneficial and brilliant and bountiful.

an8.34:4.2.eng: What eight factors do they have?

an8.34:4.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammādiṭṭhikā honti, sammāsaṅkappā, sammāvācā, sammākammantā, sammāājīvā, sammāvāyāmā, sammāsatino, sammāsamādhino.
an8.34:4.3.eng: It’s when an ascetic or brahmin has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an8.34:4.4.pli: Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatesu, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu dānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsaṃ mahājutikaṃ mahāvipphāranti.
an8.34:4.4.eng: When an ascetic or brahmin has these eight factors a gift given to them is very fruitful and beneficial and brilliant and bountiful.

an8.34:5.2.eng: and the seed sown in it is excellent,

an8.34:5.4.eng: the crop of grain will be excellent.

an8.34:6.1.eng: The absence of crop loss is excellent,

an8.34:7.1.eng: So too, when you give excellent food

an8.34:7.4.eng: for what you did was excellent.

an8.34:8.1.eng: So if a person wants excellence,

an8.34:8.3.eng: You should frequent those with excellent wisdom,

an8.34:8.4.eng: so that your own excellence will flourish.

an8.34:10.2.eng: and having attained excellence of view,

an8.34:10.3.eng: one who excels in mind proceeds,

an8.34:10.4.eng: relying on excellence in the path.

an8.34:11.2.eng: and attaining the excellence of extinguishment,
